publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l:
Quid non Mortalia pectora Cogis
Auri Saca Fames?
Fair Ones to you who hearts Comand
and Gently Sway with Fan in hand
your Fav'rite Punch a Supplyant Falls
and humbly for Assistance Calls
he humbly Calls & beggs you'll Stop
the Gothick Rage of Vander Hop
wh' invades (without prtence or right
or any Law but that of Might)
Our Pigmy land & treats our Kings
like paltry, Jdle, wooden things
has beat our Dancers out of Doors
and Called our Chastest Virgins whores
he has not left our Queen a rag on
& forc'd our George away & Dragon
has broke our Wyres nor was he Civill
to Doctor Faustus and the Devill
E'vn me he hurryed with full rage
most hoarsly Squaling of the Stage
& Faith our Fright was Very great
to see a Minister of State
Arm'd with power & Fury Come
to Force us from our little home
we Fear'd as I am Sure with reason
an Accusacon of high treasonTill Starting up Says Benameer
Treason my Friends we need not Fear
for 'gainst the brass we used no power
nor Strove to Save the Chancellour
nor did we shew the least affection
to Rochfort on Westmeath Ellection
nor did we sing McCue he Means
the Villian J'll dash out his brains
'tis no affair of State that brings
me here, nor busyness of the Kings
I'm Come to Seize you all as Debtors
& bind you Fast in Jron Fetters
from Sight of ev'ry Friend in town
till fifty pounds to me laid downFifty! quoth J! a Devilish Sume.
but Stay till the New halfepence Come
then we shall be as rich as Jews
from Castle down to lowest Stews
that sume shall then be to you told
thô now we Cannot Furnish goldQuoth he thou lovest Punch to prate
and wou'dst for ever hold Debate
but thinkest thou J have nought to do
but thus to argue Still with you
or dost thou think that J am Come
to Carry nought but Farthings home
thou Fool J n're do things by halfs
Farthings were made for Jrish Slaves
no brass for me it must be gold
or Fifty pounds in Silver told
that Can by any means obtain
Freedom for thee or for thy trainVotre tres humble Serviteur
Jm not in Jest said J, J'm Sure
but from the bottom of my belly
in Sober Sadness J must tell ye
J think it is good reasoning
that we (Fictitious men) should bring
brass Counters made by Wṃ Wood
which may as well be Understood
right Sterling as we Flesh & bllood
and Since we are but Mimick men
pray let us pay in Mimick CoinAnd thô 'tis Said that you and J
are of the Self Same Famely
and Faith I'm apt to think so too
for who is liker me than you
Just the Same grave & Aukard grace
Shews forth it self in either Face
and each of us with labour Struts
behind a Flaskett huge with gutts
we tally well in these respects
but best of all in Jntellects
for when you took the differrence learn'd
'twixt the words Sorry and Concern'd
and when upon a grave affair
amaz'd you gaz'd behind the Chair
thou Cry'd──Lord how like Punchenello
Js that Same Fatt beef witted Fellow
then prithy Coz lett us buss
and Cease to treat yoṛ kindred thus──Quoth he thou Vile Mishapen beast
thou knave am J a become your Jest
now not a puppett of you all
Shall Stirr a Step without this wall
nor Merry Andrew beat a drum
Untill you pay the aforesaid sumeThen Marching off with Solemn pace
to write dispatches for his G────
the Revell Master left the room
and us Condemn'd to Fatall doomNow Fair ones if J e're found grace
or if my Iokes did ever please
Use all yoṛ Jnterest with the Sec
(they say he's at the Ladys beck)
and thô he thirsts as much for gold,
as ever Mydas did of old
your Charms J'm Sure Can never Fail
your eyes must Jnfluence, must prvail
at your Comand he'll sett us Free
lett us to you Owe liberty
get us a lycence now to play
And (as in Duty bound) we'll pray
Punch & CompanyY08B005D
